message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Schematic Bases of Social Information Processing
Paper Abstract: The term, schema, appears to have been first used by Bartlett in 1932 in his work on recall of perceptual experience. A minimal theory is not, however, necessarily a good theory, and so one may want to inquire of the schema's literature not only if the minimum criterion of a theory has been met, but if it is a good theory. When a stimulus configuration is encountered in the environment, it is matched against a schema, and the ordering and relations among the elements of the schema are imposed on the elements of the stimulus configuration. Studies comparing the effects of memory set versus impression set on recall also point to the structuring function of schemas. Information is easier to recall, however, if it is structured in some way, and there is evidence that people will structure stimuli so as to facilitate recall. Default options may not only be inserted when a particular piece of data is missing.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Frederic Bartlett psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Frederic Bartlett - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederic_Bartlett"},{"title":"Reconstructive memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconstructive_memory"},{"title":"Schema (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schema_(psychology)"},{"title":"Donald Broadbent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Broadbent"},{"title":"List of cognitive scientists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_scientists"},{"title":"British Psychological Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Coaching_Psychologist"},{"title":"Frederick Bartlett - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Bartlett"},{"title":"Steven James Bartlett - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steven_James_Bartlett"},{"title":"List of psychologists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_psychologists"},{"title":"Category:20th-century British psychologists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:20th-century_British_psychologists"}]

## Summary of Frederic Bartlett's Psychology

Frederic Bartlett was one of the forerunners of cognitive psychology as well as cultural psychology.(no content)He held the title of Senior Lecturer of Psychology until his death in 1969 at the age of 82.

### Major Contributions

**Schema Theory and Memory:**
Frederic Bartlett was one of the first psychologists to propose Schematic theory, suggesting that the individual's understanding of the world is influenced by elaborate neural networks that organize abstract information and concepts.(no content)Bartlett's work was crucially important in demonstrating that long-term memories are neither fixed nor unchanging but are constantly being adjusted as schemata evolve with experience.

**The "War of the Ghosts" Experiment:**
Frederic Bartlett tested his idea of the reconstructive nature of recall by presenting participants with foreign folk tales, and found that participants had difficulty recalling stories accurately, with their accounts generally being shorter and manipulated to fit into more personally relevant versions.

**Interdisciplinary Work:**
Bartlett considered most of his own work on cognitive psychology to be a study in social psychology, but he was also interested in anthropology, moral science, philosophy, and sociology.

**Applied Research:**
He and Kenneth Craik were responsible for setting up the Medical Research Council's Applied Psychology Research Unit (APU) at Cambridge in 1944, where their applied research focused on issues directed from government agencies, including training and experimental designs.

Web search results for query: "Memory psychology cognitive"

Links: [{"title":"Cognitive psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_psychology"},{"title":"Memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory"},{"title":"Working memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_memory"},{"title":"Ulric Neisser - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulric_Neisser"},{"title":"Rehearsal (educational psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rehearsal_(educational_psychology)"},{"title":"Processing fluency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Processing_fluency"},{"title":"Information processing theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_processing_theory"},{"title":"Alexander Luria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Luria"},{"title":"Collective memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_memory"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_Learning,_Memory,_and_Cognition"}]

I've completed a web search for "Memory psychology cognitive". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Cognitive Psychology and Memory

Cognitive psychology is the scientific study of human mental processes such as attention, language use, memory, perception, problem solving, creativity, and reasoning.

## Types of Memory

Memory systems are a major focus within cognitive psychology. Memory is often understood as an informational processing system with explicit and implicit functioning that is made up of a sensory processor, short-term (or working) memory, and long-term memory.(no content)Working memory is a cognitive system with a limited capacity that can hold information temporarily. It is important for reasoning and the guidance of decision-making and behavior.

## Key Concepts

The two main types of memory are short-term memory and long-term memory; however, short-term memory has become better understood to be working memory. Cognitive psychologists often study memory in terms of working memory. Though working memory is often thought of as just short-term memory, it is more clearly defined as the ability to process and maintain temporary information in a wide range of everyday activities in the face of distraction.

## Historical Context

Cognitive psychology originated in the 1960s in a break from behaviorism, which held from the 1920s to 1950s that unobservable processes couldn't be studied. Noam Chomsky's 1959 critique of behaviorism, and empiricism more generally, initiated what came to be known as the "cognitive revolution".

The search results provide comprehensive information about the relationship between memory and cognitive psychology, including the structure of memory systems and the historical development of the field.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Recall memory"

Links: [{"title":"Recall (memory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_(memory)"},{"title":"Free recall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_recall"},{"title":"Recall test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_test"},{"title":"Eidetic memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eidetic_memory"},{"title":"Affective memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_memory"},{"title":"Involuntary memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Involuntary_memory"},{"title":"Verbal memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verbal_memory"},{"title":"Recovered-memory therapy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recovered-memory_therapy"},{"title":"State-dependent memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-dependent_memory"},{"title":"Eyewitness memory (child testimony) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eyewitness_memory_(child_testimony)"}]

I've performed a web search for "Recall memory" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Recall in memory refers to the mental process of retrieving information from the past.(no content)Along with encoding and storage, it is one of the three core processes of memory.

## Types of Recall

There are three main types of recall: free recall, cued recall and serial recall.

**Free Recall**: In this task, participants study a list of items on each trial, and then are prompted to recall the items in any order.

**Cued Recall**: A cued recall test is a procedure for testing memory in which a participant is presented with cues, such as words or phrases, to aid recall of previously experienced stimuli.

## Theories of Recall

The two-stage theory states that the process of recall begins with a search and retrieval process, and then a decision or recognition process where the correct information is chosen from what has been retrieved.(no content)The encoding specificity principle states that memory utilizes information from the memory trace and the situation in which it was learned, and from the environment in which it is retrieved. In other words, memory is improved when information available at encoding is also available at retrieval.

## Historical Research

In 1885, Hermann Ebbinghaus created nonsense syllables to test his own memory. He would memorize a list of nonsense syllables and then test his recall of that list over varying time periods. He discovered that memory loss occurred rapidly over the first few hours or days, but showed a more steady, gradual decline over subsequent days, weeks, and months. Furthermore, Ebbinghaus discovered that multiple learning, over-learning, and spacing study times increased retention of information.

I've performed a web search for "Recall memory" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Recall in memory refers to the mental process of retrieving information from the past.(no content)Along with encoding and storage, it is one of the three core processes of memory.

## Types of Recall

There are three main types of recall: free recall, cued recall and serial recall.

**Free Recall**: In this task, participants study a list of items on each trial, and then are prompted to recall the items in any order.

**Cued Recall**: A cued recall test is a procedure for testing memory in which a participant is presented with cues, such as words or phrases, to aid recall of previously experienced stimuli.

## Theories of Recall

The two-stage theory states that the process of recall begins with a search and retrieval process, and then a decision or recognition process where the correct information is chosen from what has been retrieved.(no content)The encoding specificity principle states that memory utilizes information from the memory trace and the situation in which it was learned, and from the environment in which it is retrieved. In other words, memory is improved when information available at encoding is also available at retrieval.

## Historical Research

In 1885, Hermann Ebbinghaus created nonsense syllables to test his own memory. He would memorize a list of nonsense syllables and then test his recall of that list over varying time periods. He discovered that memory loss occurred rapidly over the first few hours or days, but showed a more steady, gradual decline over subsequent days, weeks, and months. Furthermore, Ebbinghaus discovered that multiple learning, over-learning, and spacing study times increased retention of information.

Web search results for query: "Perception psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perception"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_Human_Perception_and_Performance"},{"title":"Perceptual psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_psychology"},{"title":"Social perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_perception"},{"title":"Cognitive psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_psychology"},{"title":"Psychology of music - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology_of_music"},{"title":"Gestalt psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gestalt_psychology"},{"title":"Cultural psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_psychology"},{"title":"Self-perception theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-perception_theory"},{"title":"Emotion perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_perception"}]

Here are the search results for "Perception psychology":

## Overview

Perception depends on complex functions of the nervous system, but subjectively seems mostly effortless because this processing happens outside conscious awareness.(no content)Perception involves both the physical senses (sight, smell, hearing, taste, touch, and proprioception) as well as the cognitive processes involved in interpreting those senses, and is essentially how people come to understand the world around them through the interpretation of stimuli.

## Perceptual Psychology as a Field

Perceptual psychology is a subfield of cognitive psychology that concerns the conscious and unconscious innate aspects of the human cognitive system: perception.(no content)Perception is one of the oldest fields in psychology, with the oldest quantitative laws being Weber's law and Fechner's law, which quantify the relationship between physical stimulus intensity and perception.

## Research Approaches

Since the rise of experimental psychology in the 19th century, psychology's understanding of perception has progressed through combining various techniques including psychophysics (which quantitatively describes relationships between sensory input and perception) and sensory neuroscience (which studies neural mechanisms underlying perception).

## Key Schools of Thought

The study of perception gave rise to the Gestalt School of Psychology, with an emphasis on a holistic approach.(no content)Gestalt psychology is a school of psychology and a theory of perception that emphasises the processing of entire patterns and configurations, and not merely individual components.

## Developmental Perspectives

Nativist and empiricist approaches to perceptual psychology have been debated, with nativists believing humans are born with all perceptual abilities needed and empiricists believing humans must learn them.

I've completed a web search on "Schema psychology cognition." Here are the key findings:

## Definition

In psychology and cognitive science, a schema describes a pattern of thought or behavior that organizes categories of information and the relationships among them.(no content)It can be described as a mental structure of preconceived ideas, a framework representing some aspect of the world, or a system of organizing and perceiving new information.

## How Schemas Function

Schemata influence attention and the absorption of new knowledge: people are more likely to notice things that fit into their schema, while re-interpreting contradictions to the schema as exceptions or distorting them to fit.(no content)People can organize new perceptions into schemata quickly as most situations do not require complex thought when using schema, since automatic thought is all that is required.

## Historical Development

Early developments of the idea in psychology emerged with the gestalt psychologists (founded originally by Max Wertheimer) and Jean Piaget. The term schéma was introduced by Piaget in 1923.

## Different Types of Schemas

The search results reveal several distinct types of schemas studied in psychology:

- **Self-schemas**: The self-schema refers to a long lasting and stable set of memories that summarize a person's beliefs, experiences and generalizations about the self, in specific behavioral domains.

- **Cultural schemas**: Cultural schema theory is a cognitive theory that explains how people organize and process information about events and objects in their cultural environment. According to the theory, individuals rely on schemas, or mental frameworks, to understand and make sense of the world around them.

- **Gender schemas**: Gender schema theory is a cognitive theory to explain how individuals become gendered in society, and how sex-linked characteristics are maintained and transmitted to other members of a culture. The theory was formally introduced by Sandra Bem in 1981.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** SURVEY
- This paper reviews and discusses existing schema theory, particularly Bartlett's foundational 1932 work
- No new methods or frameworks are proposed
- The paper examines existing research on memory, recall, and perception

**Extracted Entities (5 triples):**

1. **Schema (psychology)** - concept - Uses
   - Fundamental framework for understanding information processing and structuring

2. **Frederic Bartlett** - other - Uses

3. **Memory** - concept - Uses
   - Central to understanding how schemas organize and facilitate information retrieval

4. **Recall (memory)** - task - Uses
   - Shows how schema structure facilitates the core memory process of information retrieval
